1546031606_17AMQVbBa12XB3xFWKDnP2dCEx92T.body:
I had a similar experience, I remedied it by 

- Closing Zeronet
- going to my zeronet/data/ directory and opening up the sites.json and users.json files.

- Within these files find the site address and remove the entry section from the two files.
- Restarted Zeronet

1546939398_1JcHMiQxXHX9q3ZK2LF9rZjvg3MUt.body:
> No, it only uses bittorrent trackers to trace which peers have which sites,

Bittorrent technology is the protocol concept of grabbing data from a swarm of peers.
Zeronet technology was custom built to function on the concept of grabbing data from a swarm of peers.

I hope you can see the relation even though it is not a direct implementation.

> [quantumworld](#comment_163_1AdWXZdPUimpXoGNXUBde2CHR7gLf4onxE): My theory is ...

I suspect the knowledge curve alone will keep those newbie away. If they do manage to launch the client or visit a proxy, they will see the youth of the network and available platforms, browse around for an hour, say "That's cool" and shut it down.

The other few (who most likely have at least some kind of programming experience) will see the potential of the clean slate to create something new and better. One that better suits their image rather than the corporate mess that we see clustered all over the clear internet of today.

1548024035_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5.body:
When I dual booted I just kept my Zeronet installation in a storage folder on my Windows partition since linux can see all the Windows data nativly.

My dual boot setup is extensive. On one HDD (my primary gaming hdd) I have Windows 10 with the Windows boot loader which gives me the option to boot linux from my 2nd HDD. Then on the 2nd HDD, I have linux boot loader prompt me to boot into Ubuntu or my older copy of Windows 7 that remains on my 2nd drive. My zeronet installation is on my 2nd drive in the Windows 7 partition and this allows all three OS to access that location.

1548259475_17UY7McN5WAMD6dqnxLCFBwHYLXY9.body:
Zeronet runs locally, so if you don't exclude local traffic (localhost / 127.0.0.1)  in Firefox, it will send that traffic that is suppose to remain local, to your set proxy, which will attempt to forward it back to yourself.

But since your zeronet client is set to only display the web user interface through your own local network, it displays a gateway error instead as the local zeronet client sees the traffic originating from your http proxy instead of being local.

PS, there is an option for a proxy address in the settings panel of zeronet. From the main landing page of [ZeroHello](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1HeLLo4uzjaLetFx6NH3PMwFP3qbRbTf3D/) click the ZeroMenu (three vertical dots) and then click Configuration and scroll down to the bottom.

1548207335_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRF.body:
> [styromaniac](#comment_467_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): On 4Kave, Big Buck Bunny was fully downloaded from a peer, but the video will not play more than five seconds. Before, it played in entirety and I've checked this weekly over many months.

Could it be due to the slow loading and constant buffering of the video? I only suggest this because after I read this discussion on my local machine with Firefox and Win10, I went to 4Kave, clicked on Big Buck Bunny, and after some slow loading and streaming, it was able to load and play the video to completion without any video errors appearing during playback.  So could the corruption be occurring locally somehow? I am going to place the video temporarily on my Zeroboxes to help with the loading time and buffering to see if your error goes away. 

At the time of writing this and having the stream download, the stats page shows a count of 2 peers so if there was any corruption, I would believe I would be getting at least some of it. If I had to take a best guess, it is error'ing out on you because of the slow loading mixed with the large video playback size. 4K video over any peer network is not going to be ideal unless there are plenty of seeders or upload bandwidth which is usually lower for residential users. (hence having multiple vps helps as the faster upload pipe by multiple peers can sometimes fill the download consumption of one person.)

> [styromaniac](#comment_471_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): I think you'll have a 50/50 chance if it's not local. [...]

I'm starting to believe it was due to the slow loading, I have obtained three copies of the file in question and all three playback without error. Nice site by the way,, it looks promising.

> [styromaniac](#comment_472_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): You're welcome to use the code.

Thanks for the offer, I may take you up on that if kopykate becomes too congested and I decide to move my uploaded videos to a more individualised presentation.

> [styromaniac](#comment_472_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): To me it's like making a logo, drawing or painting. It's art.

Zeronet is our world, this is our chance to make it beautiful.

1549027708_155V1pDJWxxohR8eNgocGarkipstc.body: One simply has to gather a collection of blocklists to compile a naughty site list.

> [nickwa](#comment_23_1EFZ3dYDWVpD4kF5H9PF83HjPAehEEKKJj): Who determines what a naughty list is?  What if people that take control of the "naughty list"

The creator of each block list, They can opt-out of it.

> [quantumworld](#comment_200_1AdWXZdPUimpXoGNXUBde2CHR7gLf4onxE): Anyone that pushes censorship for your protection is almost 100% a Communist / Nazi Racist that is out to normalize hate crime

Offering a user the option to opt-in is not forcing anyone to do anything! How did you even arrive at that conclusion?
Could one not say the same thing about that [Report] button on KopyKate?

Just because you had a bad experience with a block list does not mean others will. Some people fear of link spoofing where a normal link could point to an otherwise obfuscated link such as this fake link to [ZeroWiki](/17gCoQDCAAoQkzKRiajFNUAhnVD2gSNmuC).  Don't worry, it points to MillChan Engine

> [quantumworld](#comment_201_1AdWXZdPUimpXoGNXUBde2CHR7gLf4onxE): Censorship should be up to the individual. And talking about bad zites is fine as well. However group thinking of banning Zites is just a bad idea. 

Nothing is being banned, only a cosmetic block for the local user that they can opt-out of at any time.

> [quantumworld](#comment_203_1AdWXZdPUimpXoGNXUBde2CHR7gLf4onxE): I just don't trust block lists.

I understand that, but I would not say that you are the 'average' zeronet surfer either,  but you will find that other  users are willing to trust something that renders a promise of some protection (even if it is a shallow one) rather than have nothing to trust at all. (as the desire seen in this original topic)

Much like users are more willing to visit and seed [KopyKate](/big.kopykate.bit) and [RU-Video](/1videomkrGfLUNe2RaQJqbumb4nTgbp2J) because there is a visual Report button which gives a sense of security and suggests some level of 3rd party moderation unlike Youtube(zeronet) in which everything is tolerated and you never know if the video clicked is going to be the video promised as the owner stated before that anything is acceptable. So naturally nothing will ever need to be reported.

I'm sure some people are ok with that, I'm not and avoid it.

> [styromaniac](#comment_505_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): 2016? [...]

I figured 2017 was mistaken for 2016. Still, the point was a bit off topic so there is no reason to nit-pick at it.

Back on topic, maybe I want to subscribe to a blocklist site that blocks Windows malware code repositories. That would be my choice. Usually people who subscribe to blocklists are not about to click test every entry listed. It is a trust relationship to an extent.

The trust relationship would not be broken and a problem would not arise until there is a discussion about whatever site that nobody seems to have a problem with but the reader is not able to visit.

The point I'm trying to get at is that what works or doesn't work for me will very likely be the opposite for another person. So long as that is acknowledged, tolerance to indifferent ideas and viewpoints can allow discussion.

I'm still hoping for a zite like ZeroSites that is a blocklist in which visitors can add, vote, and comment on potential sites for blocking with the site offering a toggle switch next to each site or reason category that allows bulk blocking of categories. (Block all known porn, block all known exploit, block all known government sensitive material, etc)

Why would I want such a thing you may ask? Because it's optional! And I like to keep my options open!

Am I the only one who noticed how that whole "but there is CP!" deterrent arguments have practically vanished once the Sample Blocklist was released) Even if it is not widely adopted, the opportunity for the option is enough to foster potential innovation in further development if that is what the community wants and feels necessary.

Providing a means for users to opt-in and out of blocking mechanics for sites and users is healthy for the Zeronet network so long is such things remain optional.

1549646277_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRF.body:
As much of a fan that I am of them, I don't see Zeronet music sites taking off. There's just really not a huge demand for them since music is so plentiful on the clearnet. Placing something like Deadmou5 on zeronet just feels redundant if the song is not unique enough to preserve. (There are many jewels in the ocean of garbage.)

I once envisioned a PromoBay[1]  variant site where independent artists could submit their works and the community could vote on each entry and monthly winners could be promoted / hooked into the frontpage of other Zeronet sites to spread awareness, generate hype, and shake up the norm. But such an idea is perhaps before its time.

Remember how Dubioza kolektiv became popular with their Free.mp3?[2], It was from ThePromoBay!

But nay... Maybe in another 5 or 10 years when the network's popularity increases... That is what I believe Zeronet could benefit from, so here's to wishful thinking.

[1] :" https://web.archive.org/web/20160310125025/http://promobay.org/
https://web.archive.org/web/20160304082052/http://www.promobay.org/halp
(An old version of the promobay)

[2] : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EuQLMXyGQOE
(Youtube link to Dubioza kolektiv free.mp3)
